accountingIntegration.arAgingDetail.step: Click on the "Reports" menu. Hover your cursor over "Customers and Receivables" and then select "AR Aging Detail"
Set the Date to your current Year End
Click on the "Excel" button and then "create new worksheet". Click Export and QuickBooks will create a new Microsoft Excel file containing your accounting information
accountingIntegration.customSummary.step: Click on the "Reports" menu. Hover your cursor over "Custom Reports" and then select "Summary". A customizable report window will automatically open
Click on the "Display" tab and specify the reporting period you would like to import by modifying the Date Range boxes
Under the Reporting Basis section of the display tab, select "Accrual"
Remaining on the "Display" Tab, select "Total Only" from the dropdown menu next to "Display columns by"
Select "Account list" from the dropdown menu next to "Display rows by"
Check the box labeled “Previous Period” under the "Add subcolumns for" section
Click the "Filters" Tab at the top of the report window and select "Account" as the filter on the left side and "All Accounts" from the resulting drop down menu that appears on the right side
Click OK and wait for the report to generate
Click on the "Excel" button and then "create new worksheet". Click Export and QuickBooks will create a new Microsoft Excel file containing your accounting information

accountingIntegration.title: Quickbooks Desktop
accountingIntegration.transactionDetailB: Click on the "Reports" menu. Hover your cursor over "Accountant and Taxes" and then select "Transaction Detail by Account"
Specify the reporting period you would like to import by modifying the "Date Range" boxes
Under the Report Basis section, select "Accrual"

In the "Display" Tab, ensure the following columns are enabled: Trans #, Type, Entered/Last Modified, Last Modified by, Date, Name, Name Street1, Name Street2, Name City, Name Province, Name Postal Code, Name E-Mail, Memo, Debit, and Credit
Click the "Filters" Tab at the top of the report window and select "Account" as the filter on the left side and "All Accounts" from the resulting drop down menu that appears on the right side
Click OK and wait for the report to generate
Click on the “Excel” button and then "create new worksheet". Click Export and QuickBooks will create a new Microsoft Excel file containing your accounting information

characteristic.setCriteria.unrelatedAcco: You don’t need to set any criteria.

This test helps identify certain entries that appear to record transactions to unrelated accounts, by identifying entries in which there are amounts recorded to financial statement (FS) lines that we identify as unrelated (i.e. either the debit or credit side posts only to one account number).
Note that in most large, compound entries and batched entries, this test cannot be used unless the compound/batch entries can be broken down into their individual transactions.

firmComponent.ad1: To be "affiliated" with another firm, means that your audit firm is part of a "network of firms". A "network firm" means an entity that is, or that a reasonable observer would conclude to be, part of a larger structure of co-operating entities that shares:
firmComponent.ad10: (v) training courses and facilities, where such professional resources are significant.
firmComponent.ad2: (a) common quality control policies and procedures that are designed, implemented and monitored across the larger structure;
firmComponent.ad3: (b) common business strategy that involves agreement to achieve common strategic objectives;
firmComponent.ad4: (c) the use of a common brand name, including the use of common initials and the use of the common brand name as part of, or along with, a firm name when a partner of the firm signs an audit or review engagement report; or
firmComponent.ad6: (i) common systems that enable the exchange of information such as client data, billing or time records;
firmComponent.ad8: (iii) technical departments that consult on technical or industry specific issues, transactions or events for assurance engagements;
firmComponent.ad9: (iv) audit methodology or audit manuals; or

If you agree with (a) the above account balance, or (b) the outstanding item(s) set out above, please complete and sign this letter in the space provided below and send it directly to our auditors. If you do not agree with the above information, please provide us with the details of any differences. We would appreciate receiving your response no later than %s.

If you have any questions regarding the above, please contact thao phan at %s.

Yours truly,
%s
requestList.confirmationLetter.auditorOp:
In connection with our audit, our auditors, %s, request confirmation of your account with us. Our records show an amount receivable from you of %s as at %s.

In the event that your accounting system does not permit confirmation of your entire account balance, please confirm the following item(s) was (were) outstanding and receivable from you at the above date. The amounts listed below may represent only a selection of those items making up your total balance.
requestList.confirmationLetter.closingAd:

Sincerely,
%s

riskAssessment.riskTableFsArea.headerROM:
For management estimates, include the inherent risk factors here as relevant. Inherent risk factors may include the degree to which the accounting estimate is subject to

 a)    Estimation uncertainty; and

 b)    Complexity, subjectivity, or other inherent risk factors including:

         (i)    The selection and application of the method, assumptions and data in making the accounting estimate; or

         (ii)    The selection of management's point estimate and related disclosures for inclusion in the financial statements
The assessment of inherent and residual risks of material misstatement (RMM) is made before any consideration of what audit procedures may be required.

To assess the level of inherent risk, it is important to evaluate both the probability that the risk may occur and the magnitude of the risk should it occur to arrive at an overall assessment about the risk. Auditors may find the use of scales with different levels of probability and magnitude helpful in guiding their judgments about the inherent risk. 

 Assess the potential misstatement on a scale of 1-4 (1=Very Immaterial, 2=Minor, 3=Moderate, 4=Material)

To assess the level of inherent risk, it is important to evaluate both the probability that the risk may occur and the magnitude of the risk should it occur to arrive at an overall assessment about the risk. Auditors may find the use of scales with different levels of probability and magnitude helpful in guiding their judgments about the inherent risk. 

 Assess the potential misstatement on a scale of 1-4 (1=Remote, 2= Unlikely, 3= Possible, 4=Highly Likely)
Residual RMM is the extent of the inherent risk remaining after treatment by the controls and procedures identified.

Control risk is the risk that a misstatement could occur and will not be prevented, or detected and corrected. If no reliance is planned on the operating effectiveness of controls, control risk will be at max.
Higher assessments of risk probability and risk magnitude may indicate risks that the auditor would deem as significant risks.

wpTestTypeDescription.arAgingAnalysis.la: Aging of accounts receivable by customer and aging category (e.g., current, 30-60, 60-90, etc.) compared to the previous period.

Review the aged accounts receivable trial balance and compare it to preceding year or periods. Review payments received subsequent to period end (if possible, obtain an aged trial balance as at the period-end date with subsequent collections posted on it). (Coordinate your work with the subsequent receipts testing done in the Completeness and Existence sections above.)

For all significant or material accounts over 90 days (assuming standard terms are 30 days) which have not been paid subsequent to period end, obtain the invoice date to determine exactly how old the invoice is. Unless the auditor has verified the accuracy of the aging through other procedures above, obtain documentation for each invoice supporting when the good or service was shipped.

Review any analysis or assumptions used in preparing the allowance for doubtful accounts provision and agree the amount to the general ledger. Note any changes in the assumptions or methodology used in calculating the allowance.
Agree bad debt expenses and related bad debt write-offs to supporting documentation (e.g., letter from trustees in bankruptcy), and ensure proper approval of write-offs.
Discuss with management key assumptions used in preparing the allowance. Document results of the conversation, including the individuals interviewed and the date.
Allowance for Doubtful Accounts Testing Ensure that the allowance for doubtful accounts relates to specific accounts and is adequate.
wpTestTypeDescription.arAgingAnalysis.ti: Accounts Receivable Aging Analysis and AFDA Testing
wpTestTypeDescription.arAnalyticalProced: Develop and document expectations for the period-end accounts receivable balances based on information obtained from understanding the entity.
Accounts receivable balance compared to the previous period.
Aging of accounts receivable by customer and aging category (e.g., current, 30-60, 60-90, etc.) compared to the previous period.
Number of days’ sales in accounts receivable compared to the previous period.
Investigate and document significant variances between the expectations developed and the actual accounts receivable balance. Address the following:
wpTestTypeDescription.arConfirmationTest: Files you have selected will be deleted from your Confirmation Request Letter. Would you like to continue?
Delete
Delete Files?
Agree the balances to general ledger.
Identify the large and unusual items.
Select a sample of accounts receivable invoices or balances for confirmation including the large and unusual items.

Document how the sample of accounts receivable was chosen (i.e., judgmental or using monetary unit sampling). This should include, the desired percentage of coverage (judgmental), starting point and intervals (monetary unit sampling), etc.

Where a fraud risk exists or where confirmations will be sent by fax, consider agreeing names and addresses on confirmations on test basis to telephone directories or trade publications to ensure accounts are not fictitious.
Obtain a copy of the accounts receivable sub-ledger/trial balance as at the date the accounts will be confirmed:

Obtain explanations for management's refusal and obtain audit evidence as to their validity (such as poor response rate for multi-national customers). If management’s refusal is unreasonable, record details on Form 330 for further consideration.
Determine what alternative procedures can be performed. If alternative procedures are not possible, record details on Form 330 for further consideration.
Where management refuses to allow the auditor to send a confirmation request(s):

Prepare the confirmation requests and maintain control over the requests until they are mailed. Note: Confirmations may be sent or received via facsimile for expediency, but first consider the risk of fraud (Form 522) and impact on quality audit evidence obtained.
After ___ days, with no reply received, mail a second request.
Ask management for assistance in reconciling the differences.
Assess whether the explanations provided (if any) for differences is satisfactory. If not, perform alternative procedures such as outlined in Point 6 below.
When confirmation replies indicate that a difference exists:
Agree subsequent payments to the account and to duplicate deposit slips.
Agree shipping records and sales invoices to the account.
Examine other supporting documentation.
Consider whether the test results may be indicative of a previously unidentified fraud risk.
Where confirmations are not returned or results are not satisfactory, perform alternative auditing procedures such as:
Complete confirmation statistics summary and determine whether the test objectives have been met.
Ensure that auditing procedures in related areas (e.g., sales, receipts, etc.) are coordinated where necessary.
Accounts Receivable Confirmation Testing
wpTestTypeDescription.arDefault.label1.t: Each of these tests are Canadian Auditing Standard tests used to create working papers for an engagement’s audit file. To learn more about each test, select the  icon next to each test.
wpTestTypeDescription.arDefault.title: What is sampling?
wpTestTypeDescription.cBalancesAR.label1: Investigate and document the reasons for material credit balances in accounts receivable. Consider confirmation and reclassification to accounts payable. Where the entity has significant unapplied payments, consider the impact on the A/R aging and risk of fraud or error, and consider whether additional audit procedures are necessary.
wpTestTypeDescription.cBalancesAR.title: Credit Balances in Accounts Receivable
wpTestTypeDescription.cnCutoffTesting.la: Select a sample of Credit Notes issued after year end for the period _________ after the year end date
The sample would include Credit Notes issued for more than performance materiality and possibly a random sample as well

Credit Note supporting information would be obtained to determine what period the credit note was related to (the audit year or the subsequent period) and whether adjustments to other assets and revenues would be required (Sales, A/R and possibly inventory if such was returned and was part of the Credit Note issued
Determine whether receivables have been appropriately accounted for, presented and disclosed in the financial statements in accordance with the applicable financial reporting framework.
Complete the relevant section(s) of the applicable financial reporting framework disclosure program (the 900 series of forms).
wpTestTypeDescription.crAnalysis.title: Credit Risk Analysis
wpTestTypeDescription.manualSelection.la: Sample size (to achieve test objectives) is determined by the auditor's professional judgment.
Sample results based on professional judgment.
Sample selection judgment is used to select sample items in such a way that every item in the sample has an equal chance of being selected.

Manual selection, otherwise known as Non-statististical Sampling, is defined as any sampling approach that does not have the characteristics for statistical sampling (Random Sampling) and that relies on the auditor's professional judgment to ensure a representative sample is selected.
wpTestTypeDescription.monetaryUnitSampli: Monetary-unit sampling (MUS) is a method of statistical sampling used to assess the amount of monetary misstatement that may exist in an account balance. The method is also known as dollar-unit sampling or probability-proportional-to-size sampling. Each dollar in the sample represents a unit and each unit has an equal chance of being selected. Consequently, the larger the value of the balance or transaction, the more units it will contain. This results in a bias toward selecting higher value balances and transactions in the sample.
wpTestTypeDescription.randomSampling.lab: A sample is selected on a random basis. This means that every item in the population has a known (statistically appropriate) chance of being selected. Results can be mathematically projected. Probability theory can be used to evaluate the sample results, including measurement of sampling risk. Random selection requires the use of random number tables or computer programs (CAAT's) to guarantee that each population item has an equal chance of selection.
wpTestTypeDescription.samplingConfirm.la: When designing an audit sample, the auditor should consider the purpose for the audit procedure and the characteristics of the population from which the sample will be drawn;
The auditor should determine a sample size sufficient to reduce the sampling risk to an acceptably low level.
In general when performing audit sampling we have to abide by the following:
